Model based visualization of ancient DNA damage using aRchaic

Kushal K Dey

Department of Statistics, University of Chicago

Hussein Al-Asadi

Department of Ecology and Evolution, University of Chicago
Source: vignettes/archaic.Rmd
archaic.Rmd

Introduction

aRchaic is a R/python software environment that performs model based clustering and visualization of ancient and modern DNA samples from one or more studies. This model can be used to identify distinct patterns of DNA damage and is capable of reflecting relative rates of contamination in contaminated aDNA samples.

Here is a visual representation of aRchaic on moderns, ancient samples treated with UDG library protocol and ancient samples not treated with UDG library protocol.

Figure1

aRchaic workflow

For every mismatch in a BAM file with respect to a reference genome, aRchaic records the various features of the mismatch - mismatch type, flanking bases, strand break base, strand and position of mismatch from the ends of read - into a .csv file which we call the Mismatch Feature Format (MFF) file.

Next, aRchaic fits a mixed membership model on the mismatch feature data that allows each sample to have partial memberships in more than one cluster where the clusters represent distinct mismatch feature profiles.

The cluster memberships from model fit are represented in a stacked bar chart grouped by studies (Figure 1 left), while the clusters are represented as logo plots of enrichment of their mismatch profiles against a modern background (Figure 1 right).

For example, in Figure 1, Cluster 1 (red) is primarily represented in moderns and shows no enrichment in mismatch profile with respect to modern background. Cluster 2 (blue) is represented mainly in non UDG-ancients, and highlghts enrichment of C-to-G mismatches happening at the ends of the reads, with a depletion of G on right flanking base - due to scarcity of CpG sites in genome. Cluster 3 (orange) is represented in UDG ancients and shows enrichment of C-to-G mismatches at mainly the terminal position of read with further enrichment of these mismatches at CpG sites.

In the next sections, we present a tutorial on how to generate images (like in Figure 1) starting from the BAM files for the samples.

Installation

First and foremost, the user is required to install python and R/RStudio . The version of R must be \(>=3.5\). If your R version is lower, please upgrade.

Next, the user needs to install the Python packages pysam and pyfaidx.

Upon completion of these steps, start a new R session and install aRchaic:

install.packages("remotes")
remotes::install_github("kkdey/aRchaic")

Now you can load aRchaic into R.

library(aRchaic)

To ensure reproducible results, we set the seed:

set.seed(1)

aRchaic input - MFF file

The aRchaic R package requires as input a MismatchFeatureFormat (MFF) file, which is a special type of .csv formatted file. A typical example MFF file looks like the following

mff <- read.csv(system.file("extdata","ancients","NE2_subsampled.csv",package = "aRchaic"), header = FALSE)
head(mff)
##       V1 V2 V3 V4 V5 V6      V7
## 1 AC->TC 17 48  A  A  - 1557694
## 2 AG->AC 47  9  A  T  + 4607735
## 3 TG->AT 93  1  A  C  - 5166724
## 4 TC->TT 16 50  G  G  - 4581952
## 5 AC->TG 48 31  A  C  +  207160
## 6 GG->AG 33  5  G  G  - 2912042

The first column represents mismatch type and flanking bases : (left flank base)(mismatch)(right flank base) <-> (A)(C->T)(C). The second and third columns represent the position of mismatch from 5â€™ and 3â€™ ends of reads after mapped to reference. The fourth and 5th columns represent the base 1 base upstream from 5â€™ end of read and 1 base downstream from 3â€™ end of read respectively. The 6th column contains information of which strand the read comes from, and the 7th column is an identifier for the read containing the mismatch.

archaic_prepare()

Suppose you have two folders of MFF files corresponding to two studies - one for moderns and one for ancients. We incorporate them as part of the R package itself - lets call them moderns and ancients.

  • Modern files :
moderns_dir <- system.file("extdata","moderns", package = "aRchaic")
list.files(moderns_dir, pattern = ".csv")
## [1] "NA19788_subsampled.csv" "NA19789_subsampled.csv" "NA19792_subsampled.csv"
## [4] "NA19794_subsampled.csv" "NA19795_subsampled.csv"
  • Ancient files :
ancients_dir <- system.file("extdata","ancients", package = "aRchaic")
list.files(ancients_dir, pattern = ".csv")
## [1] "NE2_subsampled.csv" "NE3_subsampled.csv" "NE4_subsampled.csv"
## [4] "NE5_subsampled.csv" "NE6_subsampled.csv"

Each of the folders has 5 MFF files corresponding to 5 samples.

First we prepare the input data to aRchaic model from the above data folders.

out <- archaic_prepare(dirs = c(moderns_dir, ancients_dir))
## Reading file  /private/var/folders/9b/ck4lp8s140lcksryyh4dppdr0000gn/T/RtmpzwN1lw/temp_libpath708d7f009463/aRchaic/extdata/moderns/NA19788_subsampled.csv 
## Reading file  /private/var/folders/9b/ck4lp8s140lcksryyh4dppdr0000gn/T/RtmpzwN1lw/temp_libpath708d7f009463/aRchaic/extdata/moderns/NA19789_subsampled.csv 
## Reading file  /private/var/folders/9b/ck4lp8s140lcksryyh4dppdr0000gn/T/RtmpzwN1lw/temp_libpath708d7f009463/aRchaic/extdata/moderns/NA19792_subsampled.csv 
## Reading file  /private/var/folders/9b/ck4lp8s140lcksryyh4dppdr0000gn/T/RtmpzwN1lw/temp_libpath708d7f009463/aRchaic/extdata/moderns/NA19794_subsampled.csv 
## Reading file  /private/var/folders/9b/ck4lp8s140lcksryyh4dppdr0000gn/T/RtmpzwN1lw/temp_libpath708d7f009463/aRchaic/extdata/moderns/NA19795_subsampled.csv 
## Reading file  /private/var/folders/9b/ck4lp8s140lcksryyh4dppdr0000gn/T/RtmpzwN1lw/temp_libpath708d7f009463/aRchaic/extdata/ancients/NE2_subsampled.csv 
## Reading file  /private/var/folders/9b/ck4lp8s140lcksryyh4dppdr0000gn/T/RtmpzwN1lw/temp_libpath708d7f009463/aRchaic/extdata/ancients/NE3_subsampled.csv 
## Reading file  /private/var/folders/9b/ck4lp8s140lcksryyh4dppdr0000gn/T/RtmpzwN1lw/temp_libpath708d7f009463/aRchaic/extdata/ancients/NE4_subsampled.csv 
## Reading file  /private/var/folders/9b/ck4lp8s140lcksryyh4dppdr0000gn/T/RtmpzwN1lw/temp_libpath708d7f009463/aRchaic/extdata/ancients/NE5_subsampled.csv 
## Reading file  /private/var/folders/9b/ck4lp8s140lcksryyh4dppdr0000gn/T/RtmpzwN1lw/temp_libpath708d7f009463/aRchaic/extdata/ancients/NE6_subsampled.csv

The output out should be a list with 2 elements - corresponding to 2 study folders. Each element is a matrix with samples along the rows, coded mismatch features along columns, with cells of the matrix recording counts of the number of times a coded mismatch pattern occurs in a sample.

archaic_prepare also saves these elements as separate .RData files in each study folder, so they can be re-used for similar analysis downstream more easily without needing to process the MFF files everytime. In fact, if you run

out2 <- archaic_prepare(dirs = c(moderns_dir, ancients_dir))
out3 <- archaic_prepare(dirs = moderns_dir)

you will see that out2 or out3 no longer process the .csv files in the folders and directly read from the .Rdata file.

We provide here the modern MFF files used in Figure 2 of our paper for reproducing the analysis.

archaic_fit()

Before modeling and visualization, we choose a directory - output_dir - to save the model output and the visualization.

We fit the mixed membership model in aRchaic onthe output from archaic_prepare(). We choose the number of clusters \(K=2\)

output_dir <- tempdir()
model <- archaic_fit(out, K = 2, output_dir = output_dir)
## The data is read as a list of matrices - processed by archaic_prepare() 
## 
## Estimating on a 10 samples collection.
## Fitting the 2 clusters/topics model.
## log posterior increase: 21212.8, done.

Alternatively, one can also input the study folder vector directly into archaic_fit().

model <- archaic_fit(c(moderns_dir, ancients_dir), K = 2, output_dir = output_dir)
## Successfully read .RData file from the folder,  /private/var/folders/9b/ck4lp8s140lcksryyh4dppdr0000gn/T/RtmpzwN1lw/temp_libpath708d7f009463/aRchaic/extdata/moderns/ CHECK : 
## Successfully read .RData file from the folder,  /private/var/folders/9b/ck4lp8s140lcksryyh4dppdr0000gn/T/RtmpzwN1lw/temp_libpath708d7f009463/aRchaic/extdata/ancients/ CHECK : 
## 
## Estimating on a 10 samples collection.
## Fitting the 2 clusters/topics model.
## log posterior increase: 20124, done.

the output model consists of

  • omega : the grades of membership to be plotted by stacked bar chart
  • theta : cluster profiles - with each column a probability distribution on coded mismatch features
  • assessment : assessment of model fit : BIC and loglikelihood

archaic_plot()

The model output, in particular omega and theta can be visualized using the archaic_plot() command.

archaic_plot(model, output_dir = output_dir, background = "modern")

After running this, go to the output directory output_dir. You should see there is a structure.pdf file for the stacked bar chart representation of the omega output from archaic_fit and for each \(k=1,2\), a logo_clus_k.pdf file visualizing the mismatch profile in theta for each cluster.

Also notice that the method clearly separates out the example modern samples from the ancient samples
